ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I audited this course, so my estimated work load is probably lower than those who took it for credit.

I really like how this course was based on case studies. This is a great way to teach the subject matter and really dive into the material.The professor is very knowledgable and made the class enjoyable. I learned a lot from her and my other classmates.

Marjorie Shansky is a wonderful professor. The small class size and the good pacing of the course led to considerable in-class discussion and lots of peer-based learning. We covered a lot of topics and I learned a ton.

I enjoyed the relaxed atmosphere of the class and professor.Marjorie Shansky really makes the course fun. She's a local lawyer who comes in once a year to teach this class, and I really appreciated her applied professional perspective. She's very engaging and is interested in students learning about what interests them and enjoying the class.
The class discussions. Because it was a small class, everyone had abundant opportunities to contribute to class discussions and we were able to discuss topics in depth.
I enjoyed reading the case studies and discussing them in class. This was helpful.I like how each student was assigned to discuss a specific case.
The opportunity to learn from a practitioner made the course material very relevant to real world scenarios.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: 3/4s of the way through the course the case-book and case study method seemed to offer diminishing returns as each case began to resemble many we had already read. Perhaps a bit more inter-disciplinary methods would have continued the excellent initial momentum. The guest lecture was fantastic and I learned a ton. Maybe another guest lecture and a field trip at the end would improve on the current method?
It's not a very traditional class (laid back syllabus and style, not lecture format, etc).I didn't mind this at all, but if you prefer structure, this might be a little too loose for you.
Perhaps have more classes where we step away from the case history and look at other materials, or have additional guest speakers.

Although I enjoyed the open discussion set-up of the course, it would have been nice to sometimes have more directed questions from the professor about how things are vs how they should be. I liked hearing my classmates opinions and I enjoyed the critical analysis discussions that we had.Also, bringing in a few more guest lecturers would be valuable. I really enjoyed our one guest speaker because he brought our discussions about land use policy to life and made the topics very real for me.
I probably would have benefitted from a few smaller written assignments along the way to make me organize the material.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Excellent on all accounts.
Marjorie Shansky was always willing and available to meet with students outside of class to discuss class material or paper topics, and she was always helpful.
THe professor was always willing to work with me and discuss topics that I was struggling with.
The instructor was always available to talk and made sure you really understood the material and its application.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I'm very interested in local government and regional solutions to environmental problems, so I found it very relevant. It lent an applied and "real-world" lens land use, which can sometimes a very broad and abstract concept.
I am interested in land use/the built environment/sustainable development and there are not enough courses about urban sustainability at FES. I am glad this class is offered.
I wanted to learn about land use policy since it is directly related to water issues in the US.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Really interested in land use policies and planning decisions, so couldn't pass it by.
It matches my interests.
SEe above response.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes, it was very good.
Yep -- it was a great course that had all the insight and discussion I expected
Yes - great review of planning/zoning law and case history, and also a great discussion of why this matters today (e.g. smart growth, climate change adaptation).
Yes. I learned a lot about land use policy and how to read cases.
Absolutely. I left feeling confident about the principles and challenges of modern zoning, planning, and environmental law.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
Yes
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you're interested in local land use, community development strategies, or protecting nature through local land use laws, this class can be very interesting and useful.
It's a great class, and largely discussion based, so do the reading.
This course is a great way to learn about land use issues by reading cases. It gave me a lot of exposure to local policy and the policy-making process.
Take notes on each caseas you go along and try to think how each fits into a broader framework.
